review.title: Effectiveness of greedily collecting items in open world games
review.abstract: Since Pokemon Go sent millions on the quest of collecting virtual monsters, an important question has been on the minds of many people: Is going after the closest item first a time-and-cost-effective way to play? Here, we show that this is in fact a good strategy which performs on average only 7% worse than the best possible solution in terms of the total distance traveled to gather all the items. Even when accounting for errors due to the inability of people to accurately measure distances by eye, the performance only goes down to 16% of the optimal solution.

metadata.title: Effectiveness of greedily collecting items in open world games

sections.text: I. INTRODUCTIONThe problem of the traveling salesman (TSP) is a well-known NP-Hard problem. It raises the following question: How can a traveling salesman visit all N cities at least once and return to his starting point in the most efficient way possible? Efficient in this context can be referred to distance, time or money. Due to its importance in the real world scenarios such as supply networks and supply chains, it has been extensively investigated and many optimization algorithms have been suggested in the literature [1], [2]. However, humans have repeatedly proven to be better than computer algorithms in certain cases of the problem [4], [5]. Another emerging scenario in which TSP is relevant are open world computer games, sometimes referred to as Free Roam, which allow players to freely explore a huge virtual world, complete missions and collect collectibles in their preferred order. Some famous games falling into this category are Grand Theft, World of Warcraft, Assased and Far Into Far.

sections.heading: II. ALGORITHM
sections.text: The algorithm of interest is based on the following game strategy: Always collect the item closest to your current position first. A player would generally use this strategy because it is simple and does not require much planning. In order to find the optimal solution, an algorithm was used that is based on an exhaustive search. It takes into account all possible permutations of the collectibles and is thus guaranteed to find the optimal solution. As the number of permutations is proportional to the factor number of collectible errors N!, this algorithm only works if N ≤ 13, which subsequently affects our analysis. sections.heading: III. RESULTS
sections.text: To illustrate this, we used an extract from the Far Cry 3 world, where collectibles are marked by jars (Fig. 1).Unsurprisingly, the performance of the greedy algorithm depends on the starting position, as shown in Fig. 2. In the first case, the route chosen by the greedy algorithm is suboptimal, resulting in a total distance of 3601 (Fig. 2 - upper left), as opposed to the optimal distance of 2764 (Fig. 2 - upper right), which is a difference of 30.2%. In the second case, a different starting location is chosen, which results in the greedy algorithm finding a solution that comes very close to the optimal solution (2961 − 2883 or a difference of 2.4%), as seen in the similar routes in the second line of the Fig.Although this example is complicated, a detailed analysis is required to quantify the performance of the greedy algorithm as optimal.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this manuscript, we examined how a greedy algorithm compares to an exhaustive search for a variant of the Traveling Salesman problem that is relevant in many open-world computer games. We found that the main advantage of the greedy algorithm is that it can be performed by a player the way he plays, since no complex calculations are required, as opposed to an exhaustive search that can only be performed by a computer. We found that the performance of the greedy algorithm is comparable to the optimal solution, with the difference depending on the number of collectibles and the choice of starting point. For N = 11, the greedy algorithm resulted in routes that are on average 7.3% longer. Even when human errors were included in the estimation of distances, the greedy algorithm was on average less than 16.9% worse than the optimal solution, depending on the degree of errors.
